abstract.text: A container view controller that implements a hierarchical interface.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A split view controller is a container view controller that manages child view controllers in a hierarchical interface. In this type of interface, changes in one view controller drive changes in the content of another.

Split view interfaces are most suitable for filterable content or navigating content hierarchies, like traversing the folders and notes within the Notes app to view each note. In the Notes app, selecting a folder in the primary sidebar shows the list of notes in that folder, and selecting a note from the list shows the contents of that specific note in the secondary view.

When you build your app’s user interface, the split view controller is typically the root view controller of your app’s window. The split view controller has no significant appearance of its own. Most of its appearance is defined by the child view controllers you install.

You can’t push a split view controller onto a navigation stack. Although it’s possible to install a split view controller as a child in some other container view controllers, doing so isn’t recommended in most cases. For design guidance, see
In iOS 14 and later,
supports column-style layouts. A column-style split view controller lets you create an interface with two or three columns by using
with the appropriate
Use the
style to create a split view interface with a two-column layout. This style of split view controller manages two child view controllers, placed in the primary and secondary columns.
Use the

style to create a split view interface with a three-column layout. This style of split view controller manages three child view controllers, placed in the primary, supplementary, and secondary columns.
Before iOS 14,

supported just one split view interface style with a primary view controller and a secondary view controller. This classic interface style applies to split view controllers created using any other approach than
. Split view controllers with the classic interface have a
of
and they don’t respond to any of the column-style APIs introduced in iOS 14 and later.
In a column-style split view interface, use the
and

methods to set and get view controllers for each column. The split view controller wraps all of its child view controllers in navigation controllers. If you set a child view controller that’s not a navigation controller, the split view controller creates a navigation controller for it. The split view controller returns your original view controller through
, but its
property contains the navigation controller it used to wrap your view controller. After you assign view controllers to specific columns, you can show and hide those columns using
or
In a classic split view interface, you can configure the child view controllers using Interface Builder or programmatically by assigning the view controllers to the
property. In cases where you need to change either the primary or secondary view controller, it’s recommended that you do so using the
and
methods. Using these methods (instead of modifying the
property directly) lets the split view controller present the specified view controller in a way that’s most appropriate for the current display mode and size class.

The split view controller performs collapse and expand transitions in response to certain changes in its interface. For example, transitions occur when the interface’s size class toggles between horizontally regular and horizontally compact, when a user interaction hides or shows a column, or when you hide or show columns programmatically. The split view controller works with its
object to perform collapse and expand transitions. The delegate is an object you provide that adopts the
protocol.

In a column-style split view interface, when the interface is collapsed, you can show a different view controller than your primary, supplementary, or secondary. Set the desired view controller for the
column using
. If you want to further customize transitions for collapsing and expanding the interface, see
For information about managing transitions in classic split view interfaces, see

A split view controller’s current display mode represents the visual arrangement of its child view controllers. It determines how many of its child view controllers are shown, and how they’re positioned in relation to each other. For example, you can arrange the child view controllers so that they appear side-by-side, so that only one at a time is visible, or so that one is partially obscured by the others.
You don’t set the display mode directly; instead, you set a preferred display mode by using the

property. The split view controller makes every effort to respect the display mode you specify, but it may not be able to accommodate that mode visually because of space constraints. For example, the split view controller can’t display its child view controllers side-by-side in a horizontally compact environment. For possible configurations, see
After you set the preferred display mode, the split view controller updates itself and reflects the actual display mode in the
property. If you just want to change which columns are shown, try using
or
. The split view controller will determine how to update the display mode to display the desired columns.
There are several ways for user interaction to change the current display mode.
The split view controller installs a built-in gesture recognizer that lets the user change the display mode using a swipe. You can suppress this gesture recognizer by setting the
property to
. For example, you might set this property to
if you want your primary view controller to always be visible.
If
is

, the split view controller also presents a special bar button item for changing the display mode. The split view controller manages the behavior, appearance, and positioning of this item. It appears as a sidebar toggle icon for
and as a back-chevron icon for
and
. Tapping this button transitions to a new display mode based on the current display mode and split behavior.
For three-column split view interfaces—those with a
of
—another property that affects display mode is
. When this property is
, the split view controller presents another bar button item for toggling the display mode to and from
. The split view controller manages the behavior, appearance, and positioning of this item. It appears as a double-arrow icon. When a user taps this button, it toggles the display mode to or from

A split view controller’s split behavior controls how its secondary view controller appears in relation to the others. You can configure this behavior so that the secondary view controller always appears side-by-side with the others, so that it’s partially obscured by the others, or so that it’s displaced offscreen opposite the others to make space for them.
You don’t set the split behavior directly; instead, you set a preferred split behavior by using the
property. This change takes effect after the next layout occurs. The split view controller reflects the actual split behavior in the
property. The value of the
property affects which display modes are available for the split view controller. For possible configurations, see
You can specify custom widths for the primary and supplementary columns of the split view interface by adjusting
and
. If you don’t specify values for these properties, they default to
, and the system determines the appropriate behavior based on the available space.

A split view controller interposes itself between the app’s window and its child view controllers. As a result, all messages to the child view controllers must flow through the split view controller. Messages are forwarded as appropriate. For example, view appearance and disappearance messages are sent only when the corresponding child view controller actually appears onscreen.
If you assign a value to the split view controller’s

property, it preserves any child view controllers that have their own valid restoration identifier. During the next launch cycle, the split view controller restores the preserved view controllers to their previous state. The child view controllers of a split view controller may use the same restoration identifiers. The split view controller automatically stores additional information to ensure that each child’s restoration path is unique.

A true value.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the
API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
Navigational controls that display in a bar along the top of the screen, usually in conjunction with a navigation controller.
A container view controller that defines a stack-based scheme for navigating hierarchical content.
The items that a navigation bar displays when the associated view controller is visible.
A container view controller that manages navigation between pages of content, where a subview controller manages each page.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
A tab subclass that represents the system’s search tab.
A container view controller that implements a hierarchical interface.
Styles that apply a visual effect to the background of a primary view controller.
Constants that describe the columns within the split view interface.
The column for the view controller that’s shown when the split view controller is collapsed.
Constants that describe the possible arrangements for a split view interface.
Only the secondary view controller is shown onscreen.
Constants that determine the visibility of the display mode button.
Constants that indicate the side on which the primary view controller sits.
Constants that describe the possible ways that the child view controllers appear in relation to each other.
The sidebars displace the secondary view controller instead of overlapping it, moving it partially offscreen.
The sidebars are layered on top of the secondary view controller, leaving the secondary view controller partially visible.
The sidebars and secondary view controller appear tiled side-by-side.
Constants that describe the number of columns the split view interface displays.
The split view interface displays two columns.
The split view interface displays three columns.
The split view interface uses the classic split view style.
The default value to apply to a dimension.
The delegate you use to manage changes to a split view interface.
The current arrangement of the split view interface.
A button that changes the display mode of the split view controller.
A setting that determines whether the display mode button is visible in the interface.
Dismisses the view controller in the specified column of the split view interface.
Creates a split view controller from data in an unarchiver.
Creates a split view controller with the nib file in the specified bundle.
Creates a split view controller with the specified column style.
A Boolean value that indicates whether only one of the child view controllers displays.
The maximum width, in points, for the primary view controller’s content.
The maximum width, in points, for the supplementary view controller’s content.
The minimum width, in points, for the primary view controller’s content.
The minimum width, in points, for the supplementary view controller’s content.
The preferred arrangement of the split view interface.
The preferred width, in points, of the primary view controller’s content.
The relative width of the primary view controller’s content.
The preferred behavior that determines how the child view controllers appear in relation to each other.
The preferred width, in points, of the supplementary view controller’s content.
The relative width of the supplementary view controller’s content.
Specifies whether a hidden view controller can be presented and dismissed using a swipe gesture.
The background style of the primary view controller.
The width, in points, of the primary view controller’s content.
The side on which the primary view controller sits.
Presents the provided view controller in the specified column of the split view interface.
Presents the view controller in the specified column of the split view interface.
Presents the specified view controller as the primary view controller in the split view interface.
Presents the specified view controller as the secondary view controller of the split view interface.
Specifies whether the secondary view controller shows a button to toggle to and from the secondary-only display mode.
The current behavior that determines how the child view controllers appear in relation to each other.
The style that determines the number of columns that the split view interface displays.
The width, in points, of the supplementary view controller’s content.
Returns the view controller associated with the specified column of the split view interface.
The array of view controllers the split view controller manages.
The methods adopted by the object you use to manage changes to a split view interface.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
An object that manages a tab in a tab bar.
A control that displays one or more buttons in a tab bar for selecting between different subtasks, views, or modes in an app.
A container view controller that manages a multiselection interface, where the selection determines which child view controller to display.
An object that describes an item in a tab bar.
An object that manages a collection of tab objects.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
An array of view controllers that are children of the current view controller.
The identifier that determines whether the view controller supports state restoration.
Create a composite interface by combining content from one or more view controllers with other custom views.

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
